description.text:
Attachment for a KÃÂÃÂ¤rcher vacuum cleaner to the 1,5KW spindle of a
YOOCNC CNC6040. The design is PARAMETRIC,
so you can change the diameter of your spindle, of the vac hose, the height and the bolt sizes at will. Blog-postings:
http://marcuswolschon.blogspot.de/2012/09/3d-printed-vacuum-cleaner-attachment.html
http://marcuswolschon.blogspot.de/2012/11/workshop-vacuum-cleaner-attachment-for.html License is CC-BY-NC-SA
So you may make one yourself and improve the design but not sell the design or made parts and always give attribution. THIS DESIGN HAS BEEN MOVED TO YOUMAGINE:
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/cnc-spindle-vacuum-cleaner-attachment-v1-7 Resons:
http://marcuswolschon.blogspot.de/2014/01/leaving-thingiverse.html

Combine upper and lower parts using long M5x20 or M5x25 bolts.
Both upper parst connect using some 3mm filament or an M3x10 bolt.
The tubes are slightly tapered.
So you slide them on as until they sit tight.
Then secure the assembly on your spindle using an M5x25 nut and bolt.
Add glue to make things super secure and sealed if you want to.

description.text:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v-lorciobkc&feature=youtu.be This extruder maximizes travel in X and Z axis, by positioning the motor in lowest possible position on the carriage. The motor is perpendicular to X axis, mounted by two screws tightening it from the top (none of four standard M3 screws are used). The body is mounted on the carriage only with one screw, allowing very quick detachment/attachment (it's sort of clip-on really). It's also very rigid at the same time - no wobble even at high speeds. NEW : The carriage can also be used with zMorph DREMEL mount - so you can turn your printer into a milling machine!
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:46986 (more information on zMorph 3d printer can be found on http://reprap.org/wiki/Zmorph)

Print both extruder_body.stl and carriage.stl. Attach carriage to your X axis using 4 LM8UU bearings (push-fit). Assemble the body : attach nozzle (J-head mount compatible), motor, hobbed pulley on M8 bolt, bearings, guidler (use Greg Frost design), then small and big herringbone gears.  
Attach long screws with springs. NOTE : the design has improved, now you can easily attach/detach springs from the top.  Another thing : you SHOULD get a hobbed PULLEY, and mount it on M8 screw (between two M8 nuts). It will work with typical hobbed bolt, but it's not recommended.  
Clip the extruder to the carriage, and insert one horizontal screw in the bottom part.   
Fishbone gears and idler are taken from another design, link+attribution coming soon!

comments.text: Are you kidding me? Changing filament on this is a nightmare. Ok, if you have it fully assembled, you need to remove 12 t-slot nuts and bolts. If you leave the top unbolted always, you need to remove 6 screws. Then you remove the top of the spindle (top circle) from the tabs. Now you can replace you abs. Now here is the part that takes an hour of frustration and may require two people, gettng the top of e spindle back on the tabs! This is s very very difficult task and this design could easily be changed to require one thumb screw in the middle, if you think about it. I am working on that modification now and will post if it works out. Anyway, then you have to put the six or twelve screws back in. And you are done. This filament spindle is flawless otherwise. It works really well except for the poor design for changing filament.

Proxxon MICROMOT 50 drill stand.
Not yet quite assembled, I'm still waiting for some parts.
I made some changes to 3D printed parts. I hope that this will now be finally done. Later, I will describe the assembly and other material that we need (screws, bearings, axles ...), and add photos of the finished product.
I made a bracket without LM8UU 8mm Linear Ball Bearing, only plastic bushings. You can choose between Ball Bearings (bracket.stl) and without bearings (bracket-WB.stl). With the bearings works much better, driving more smoothly and easier

At the drilling of printed circuit boards with drill bits of tungsten alloys, I always had problems with breaking of drill bits. Solution is stand for the drill, which can be expensive. Since I have 3d printer at home (also homebrew), I said to myself, let's do prefer to make a DIY stand. On eBay I found a linear bearings for a few bucks set, which I bought and added some of own stuff and that's it. I think the instructions are not required, picture says more. I took for the leads seamless stainless steel tube with a diameter of 8mm .
For questions I am always available.
Successfully making and drilling!
Branko!

v1.1 - Updated 4/28/14 This is a remix of Serin117's "M3 Predator Pistol - Mass effect" found at:

Another creation in the theme of organizing things.   Yet another project in hopes of impressing my wife with the usefulness of having a 3D Printer.  
The original case for this project was to organize a makeup box but this thing could be applied to organizing any drawer or box.

There are two major variants of walls in each of six sizes from one tab to six (180mm).   The largest being driven by the printable area of my reprap.  The two variants are one with a tabbed slot that allows two walls to be joined and one without that tabbed slot.  
There are also three joiners with the large cross being used to secure two tabbed walls and the small cross being used for the tabless walls.   The straight joiner is used to secure the joining of two walls with a tab.   Join tabbed walls by inserting the small tabs in the slot provided, force the two walls together, and then use the straight joiner to reinforce the join.  
PLEASE NOTE!   This thing requires a reasonably precise printer in order for things to fit.   However, if you printer is REALLY precise the joins may actually float a little given the tolerances that I have played into the design.   With my printer things join reasonably well without a lot of force but are still reasonably secure.   I would recommend a drop of adhesive on each joint.  
The works shown were printed using PLA with a layer height of .32 and a fill of .2

Simple parametric clip to attach the glass plate to the heated bed of a Reprap printer. You probably need to customize and tweak this if you want to use it, see the instructions tab.

• Measure your plate thickness, PCB + glass plate and choose a 'gap' width that is a few tenths of a mm smaller (you may have to tweak a bit before printing in bulk).
  • Measure the distance from the rim of the build plate to the rim of the glass plate (the 'border') and from that decide what the values of 'l1' and 'l2' should be. The 'depth' of the clip will be l1 + l2. An overlap of about 3mm works for me, so if l1+l2 > border + 3, you should be fine.
  • A clip width of 10mm works for me. If you make it too small, the clip may twist off.

This is a typical example for an ideal use of a 3D printer, like printing spare parts. Especially if they are out of stock and you can't buy them anymore. And there is a big advantage, you can make them better, more stable and you have the possibility to adapt them to your needs.
In this case the left mount of a screen has been broken.
I decided to separate the fastening angle from the mount housing so it is adjustable to warping walls or ceilings.
The screen was mounted to the wall before, now it is mounted to the ceiling. With more distance to the wall there is room for pictures. The right mount has a metallic bush bearing. Therefore we didn't replaced the complete mount housing but only the angle. That means you have to cut the integrated angles and to drill 4 holes for the new fastening angle. For this the left mount housing is suitable as drill template
Inside you can use the M4 pocket strap for the nuts. The large mounting angle is not suitable for fastening to the wall. The hole spacing is too small for this weight. If you want a more stable one, just tell me. You don't need to add nuts between the angle and the mount cap as shown in the pictures.
And please don't use such long screws if you have shorter ones ;-)

description.text: My kids want to wipe their mouths on the hand towels in the bathroom after brushing their teeth, which is gross. I wanted them to start using facecloths, but they are so small they always fall off of the towel bar. This clip attaches to the facecloth and then clips onto the towel bar. UPDATED 2010-05-18 RobertHunt sent me an optimized STL file. I skeinforged it and did a test print to make sure it worked okay. Everything looked great (see uploaded picture of part on the MakerGear heated build platform -- it's Robert's). I recommend that you download that file since it's way smaller!

comments.text: My spindle got stuck on the first one I printed, but it was thick enough to handle the towel.  The second one I printed was 3 times as big as the first one and didn't hold the towel 3 times better.  I'm thinking I could print 3 for the same plastic as 1 and still have usable clips.

title: Mechanical Transfer Press 600Ton with Link Lever system ( Working model Scale 1:25 )

description.text:
This is a Mechanical Transfer Press 600Ton model, replica in scale 1:25, that i made for training purpose. This machine has a Link Lever System to reduce the speed while pressing the material. It is used to form Steel, starting by Rolls, by Deep Drawing process, The machine has 8 Transfer Tools inside, togheter with the replica of the Transfer system. There are 5 Spring aided bed cushions, below 5 of the Tools. The machine can be moved by rotating the Flywheel using the handle. The Front and the Top of the machine can be opened to show the Link Lever system inside. To assembly the plastic components are also necessary some extra parts :

  • 4 Threaded bars Diam 5/6 mm with Nuts to close the Uprights of the machine,

  • 1 Rubber to connect the replica of the motor to the Press rod,

  • 5 Pen Springs for the Lower ejectors/Cushions.

    • The model is ok and debugged, the most of the parts can be stamped without support material. I uploaded it splitted into Seven files translated starting from the original Rhino model, here i had to put a traslation in DXF ( Meshed ) and splitted the model into different files (7) for size reason, but it looks ok for printing,,each component is on different layer.. You can also merge the files, layers name are unique and parts are in position respect to zero point. The model are in Millimeters. If you like to get the original 3dm file, just contact me .. The model, once stamped, looks and works fine, but it's a huge challenge to produce it because the parts are many and it will need a lot of hours for stamping all of them. I designed this in 2 months and printed while sketching it in the same time, so to debug each parts before to proceed further. There are # 276 components in total to Print for a printing time of about 150/180 Hours. :) [ Excluding issues eh eh .. ] Here some link to videos i made to show the machine in function :
  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PAyUSs72Ae0
  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=47I6XdRxpEw
  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OElmYyHw-dc
  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jgwpS0-TafI

Download all the 7 Files. The file #5 ( Skecth ) is just for understanding the funcion of the Link lever system, and not for printing.

  • Open all the files, on each layers you'll find the objects to print, create the.STL's and print them.

  • The most of the parts works without support.
    • To assemble the machine you will also need just some glue and :

  • 4 Threaded bars Diam 5/6 mm with Nuts to close the Uprights of the machine,

  • 1 Rubber to connect the replica of the motor to the Press rod,

  • 5 Pen Springs for the Lower ejectors/Cushions.

    • For any further question just contact me ..

I've collected a full set of mendel parts, and replaced as many STLs as possible with existing OpenSCAD versions - including the latest versions of Vik's files and the OpenSCAD rework of Wade's geared extruder.  I'm working to replace the remaining STLs with OpenSCAD re-works.  Also on the todo list is unifying various configuration options into a single config file, and extracting more shared code into mendel_misc.inc.
I will gladly accept patches, pull requests, additional files, etc.  Let's hack on the mendel like a proper software project!

The git repository is hosted here: http://github.com/timschmidt/parameterized-mendel Install git, and run the following command to check out the most recent version: git clone git://github.com/timschmidt/parameterized-mendel.git

comments.text: I've been playing around with something similar. I'm working from the Mini Mendel design to make a parametric version, which could easily be scaled back up to Mendel size by changing the 3 variables: rod size (necessary only for structural strength) and x/y dimensions (z is a function of y).
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: Awesome, there's a few tweaks I've been meaning to do to some of the openscad versions of parts and I think this will finally give me the push to do it now that it's all on github.  :)
comments.author: tbuser

comments.text: I've started integrating the modified X carriage for the BitsFromBytes hot ends back into the mainline X carriage OpenSCAD files as a configurable option.  x_carriage_upper and mendel_misc.inc are already (crudely) done.  This is a great example of how OpenSCAD allows us to improve mendel's CAD files greatly.  It's a great time to dive in, and lend a helping hand!
comments.author: timschmidt

comments.text:
but, why OpenSCAD and why develop on the Mendel-model outside the
project
Ã‚Â´s existing repository and without an official word by the Reprap
project maintainer ?
ArenÃ‚Â´t there enough forks already?
comments.author: MarcusWolschon

comments.text: Hi. I'm one of the core team. I'm supportive of the work Tim is doing here. There is a lot of work going on to make the project more accessible - using git as it happens. At this stage we do not need to be worried about forks. They are part of the way it works - one man's fork is another's mainstream etc.
comments.author: MarcusWolschon

comments.text: I LOVE that idea of being able to specify what pieces you have access to, and having a design/BOM/etc built for you automatically.
comments.author: vik

comments.text: The choice of OpenSCAD is simple: OpenSCAD treads CAD files like software - they're text that can be patched, versioned, and developed collaboratively.  You simply can't do that with other CAD software.  Plus, it's open source.
comments.author: MarcusWolschon

comments.text: +1 on the easy diff operations of OpenSCAD text files.  Being able to merge files back into other branches is definitely one of git's strength and helps manage the perma-forking dilemma.
comments.author: timschmidt

description.text:
The silent_runner is a small high performance model airship with a full do it your self documentation available at:
http://www.silent-runner.net All parts are cheap and easy to assemble. Build your airship today and stop wasting battery power to low efficiency planes and quadrocopters, but start over with endless endurance and amazing grace. The whole project is undergoing finetuning and improvements, thus feedback is much appreciated.

Silent runner i4 datasheet:
length:.......... 2.1 m
diameter:...... 0.5 m
mass:........... 300 g
motors:..........1x Brushless
ESC:..............1x 10 A
battery:.......... LiPo 2S 1000/500 mAh
speed:............3 m/s
endurance:.....90 min
payload:.........40 g The silent_runner consists of several parts and materials, including RC electronics and printed parts. Printed parts as listed here should be sliced and printed with care as they are optimized for low weight and thus have a filigree structure. You need: 1x front rod connector
1x motorring
1x motorring1
1x motorring2
5x rudergelenk
1x ruderhalter 1
1x ruderhalter 2
1x ruderhorn The full documentation including a full list of parts can be found under the following link:
http://www.silent-runner.net/ This project is initiated and together with the greatly appreciated help of other helium heads developed by the Projekt Windreiter team: www.windreiter.de

Starting from this idea http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:273805 I have created this version for my RepRap Mendel. It works in the same way and you must follow the instructions from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:273805. I have used POM 8X10X12 from SKF for linear bearing, M5 nut fixed with M2.5 screw and M2.5 nut. The limit switch is the Z limit switch from Mendel, and it must be inverted (changed) from Normal Closed to Normal Open. The construction is useful not only for auto bed leveling but also for zeroing without the need to adjust/tune the position of limit switch on Z shaft.

title: Pololu Maestro 12 servo controller case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
A case for Mini Maestro 12 servo controller from Pololu. Features a tight hole for USB cable (dimension of the "socket" is 9.7mm x 6.7mm). Thanks to that there is low risk of unplugging cable my mistake and its very difficult to damage the on board USB socket.   
Board is attached to it with 2 M2x8mm screws (preferably ISO7046) and M2 nuts.   
Can use M2.5 screws that are slightly bigger in diameter than holes in board. This will make board securely attached to case without use of nuts.   
I'll also add a fitting top cover soon.  
p.s. The STL model can be reported as "not manifold" but still it slices perfectly fine with Slic3r 1.0.1 and prints as well (as you can see in attached photos)

2x M2x8mm DIN965/ISO7046/PN82208 screw
2x M2 nut

description.text: Bottom joint of a bike that I am building
The idea is to build a 3D printed bamboo bike. Bamboo bikes involve lot of manual labor and a jig. If all the lugs are printed and then reinforced then the manufacturing would be much easier.

comments.author: moreshk

comments.text: Thanks all, I have already made a few bamboo bikes before. They involved mitering and using jigs and caused tons of manual labor. The joints were made using epoxy and natural fiber. I think I am going to use these plastic lugs only to replace the jig and the hard part of holding the frame together at the onset. Once the frame is ready I will reinforce using epoxy and natural fiber. I have the complete frame ready with all the lugs and will get to uploading the rest of the frame lugs soon. Pics to follow. I am looking for someone with expertise in FEA methods to stress test the joints, may be the natural fiber (hemp) reinforcements may not be necessary !

comments.text:
Printed one inPLA and one in ABS. The PLA one is perfect and rigid enough. After several attempts, I finally got the ABS settings correct and it printed perfectly, HOWEVER, the walls are too thin and flexes too much. I tried having a go with sketchup to make the walls thicker, but I am defintely not a 3d designer, and got nowhere after several hours. The vertical adhesion is not great and as there is no fill all the way through the straight bits, it is much weakened.
Printing with Flashforge Creator Pro:
PLA:
215C with bed at 30C

Simple swivelling casters, for relatively lightweight furniture. Although I seem to be able to lean most of my weight on one with no trouble at all, you might want to do a destructive strength test on a printed hub before fitting this on something like a couch/sofa.
Since a couple of castors somehow fell off an item of furniture when moving out of my last flat, I figured I would try out printing replacements, since buying just a couple of new ones seemed about as expensive as printing them (getting ones that actually fit this thing were more so).
The kind of castor that I'm substituting this for is shown, and I've also made a wheel version with 1mm walls and spoke-like infill (cross-section pictured) as part of the model in a similar form to those injection-moulded wheels. This should optimise strength/weight ratio, but feel free to use the blank model with any infill style you prefer.

• Ask me if you want this in a different size, or edit it with the STEP files provided in something like FreeCAD.
  • Print out two wheels and a hub for each castor. PLA is great for low friction.
  • Meanwhile cut off a piece of M8 studding, i used about 75mm (3") each.
  • Ream M4 holes with a drill bit so that a bolt will slide through them smoothly. Optionally grease the holes (veg oil works fine).
  • Fit an M4x40mm bolt with a few M4 washers and an M4 locknut, plus some washers & locknuts on the M8 studding (locknuts are best for allowing the part to swivel freely while holding it together tight enough, but I seem to have misplaced the packet of M8 nyloc nuts that I had, so full-hex-nuts are in the photo).
    • Make some more complicated derivatives with wheel-brakes etc. if you want to. :)

comments.text: Are there any good specs on which plastic is better for weight loads? I'm curious how well this would work for an office chair fix.  So far most of the PLA and ABS stuff I've made is extremely strong but I'm sure a big part of it comes down to the design.
comments.author: futile

comments.text:
When creating a structural part with FDM/FFF 3D printing, likely the most important consideration is to design it such that the greatest stress on the part is in the same plane that the part was printed, as imperfect bonding between each layer can easily result in a part fracturing between laminations if it encounters significant shear or peel stress.
In general, PLA is noticeably more rigid than ABS, with roughly equivalent strength, and more reliably bonds between layers without the use of a heated build chamber, however two caveats are that PLA will quickly lose its rigidity above 60°C, and since ABS is a copolymer blend, no ABS is ever identical, and depending how much you spend on it, can have wildly varying strength: http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=tensile+strength+of+acrylonitrile-butadiene-styrenehttp://www.wolframalpha.com/in... (from 31 to 124MPa in that dataset as of writing).
I happen to have a couple reels of cheap ABS that displays depressingly low fracture toughness unless it's printed at a temperature that necessitates a fume hood, which I don't currently have.

remixed_from.author: Maundy
remixed_from.title: How to create your own 3D Printed iPhone Case

description.text: I've been wanting to print a custom case for my phone for awhile now and finally decided to go for it. I'm a huge WordPress fan so this speaks to my inner-geek. Using the Sketchup file at http://www.instructables.com/id/How-to-create-your-own-3D-Printed-iPhone-Case-from/ I added the logo and other design elements. For reference this is the iPhone 4 GSM model. My understanding is this should also fit the 4S GSM model (I hope so anyway, that's the phone I have) Doh! Turns out the CDMA version of the iPhone 4 is the one that matches the 4S. I've now added both the 4 (GSM) and 4S (which is also CDMA 4) as separate downloads.

The first time I printed this it ended up being too small so I scaled up 1.02 in RepG and that seems to fit pretty good. Depending on your printer settings and calibration your mileage definitely may vary. Good thing is it doesn't take very long to print if you get it wrong the first few times. I printed with zero shells to get the thin features of the Wordpress logo to come through well.

A lasercut rack/caddy for storing and transporting herbs and spices in style!

This thing is designed to be lasercut from 3mm thick plywood (I used 3mm thick Bamboo 5 ply.) You will also need: -M4 x 20mm set screws. Quantity: 12 (I used pan-heads with a flat head slot.)
-Stainless rods 186.4mm long (doesn't have to be exact!) Quantity: 6 The stainless rods are actually scrap 1/4" tube, which I polished to give a brushed stainless look. Then I cut to length and tapped each end to M4 to take the set screws.
Just make sure the bore of your tube is suitable to take an M4 tap, I wasted time on a few pieces which I thought were the same as the rest but actually had a bore that was over 4mm diameter. When lasercutting make sure you set the four bits of detail on the letter S at the start and end of SPICES on the side pieces to only engrave, so that you don't cut the tabs off. Have a look at the drawing, on the red piece the blue lines should only be engraved. Once you have lasercut the pieces (two of everything except the base) you can finish them with whatever coating or paint you like. I used a clear polyurethane gloss varnish and gave it two coats. Once dry I laid one end piece down and slotted the handle, side and base pieces into it and then placed the other end piece into position. I found mine would stay together like this whilst I fixed the tube and screws into place, as long as I wasn't too rough. Finished dimensions are approximately 193mm long x 104mm wide x 230mm high.

8mm spring needed for Dual Z Arm

Optimized for innerdiameter bug. Dual span V2.0 with 5mm is a bit less tighten belt.
Now new:
Dual span V2.1 8mm
Perfect one for my belt, easy tension adjust, just move left or right for more/less tension. Move great @ 10mm/min up to 300mm/min.
Faster not tested but i think it's possible. Update: It will be better to print endsupport and holder parts with more infill. I used only 25% and one of the endsupport is brocken because belt tension. Update2: Add some arm for 17mm nut. Attention! Please check before print! I don't need it, so I don't print it for myself but it should be right. Update3: Forgot to declare: You will need a longer Z bar. Mine is around about 420mm active and 430mm passive one. Update4: Find some other (maybe better?) solution for belt spanner:

So. I was getting ready for a vendor golf event, and decided that I wanted to somehow get Rodney Dangerfields putter from Caddyshack - however, optics are so old school when the iPhone has everything needed for the ultimate putter.  While out shopping at a sports store, I saw the iPing product (they give their app away, charge $30 for the mount) and I made one - with high hopes that someone wrote the app I so badly wanted.

Do this in any plastic you like - works great in both PLA and ABS.  40% fill should be fine too - I opted for wall thickness on this so that it would just lay down a minimum of shells and call it done.  As this part is narrow, when printing in PLA, no brim is really needed.  The rear gap should be enough to mount on any putter, and then slide it up the shaft and it should be nice and snug.
Don't try driving with this - however, if you do something crazy - just post pictures.

This iconic sculpture is in the ground floor lobby of the Asian Art Museum. Nandi, approx. 1400-1500
India; Tamil Nadu state
Granite
Gift of the Atholl McBean Foundation, B68S3 The bull Nandi is the faithful mount of the Hindu deity Shiva. In southern India, a large sculpture of Nandi would usually be placed in front of the main sanctuary of a temple to Shiva. It would face the sanctuary, so that Nandi could gaze adoringly at the representation of his master enshrined there. Because of this orientation, worshipers entering the temple compound would approach the sculpture of Nandi from behind. Here, Shiva's bull is decked with garlands, strings of bells, an elaborate blanket, and other decorations carved into the stone. In the temple, it would also have been wreathed in real flowers and fabrics. Scanned using a Canon S95 and the 123D Catch desktop app.
Slice with 2-3 extra shells and 20%+ infill to avoid warping and peeling. Use support to allow for the overhanging chin (Skeinforge will generate a minimal amount of support).

description.text:
Mythical bird-man, approx. 1775-1850
Central Thailand
Wood with remnants of lacquer, gilding and mirrored glass inlay
Gift from Doris Duke Charitable Foundation's Southeast Asian Art Collection, 2006.27.24 Mythical bird-men and -women are among the the wondrous creatures that inhabit the Eden-like Himavanta Forest of Buddhist legend. They are frequently depicted in Thai sculptures, paintings, and other mediums. Wooden figures such as this were used in several sorts of royal ceremonies. One such statue is mentioned in the description of the coronation of King Rama IV in 1851, where it is said to have contained a relic of the Buddha. The custom of using such figures in royal ceremonies most likely went back centuries. Such statues have rarely survived, and only a handful are known. Several are in the National Museum, Bangkok. The spire of the figure's crown was replaced at some point, presumably in the twentieth century. Scanned using the 123D Catch iPhone app, repaired using Meshmixer and mirrored symmetrically.
Print with support material for the overhanging arms and wings.

description.text:
This is another classic robot, named Maria, from the 1927 science fiction movie "Metropolis". It is printed in 3 sections using PLA on a MakerBot Replicator 2.
I've taken a fair amount of poetic license on the details, but I think it captures the essence of the original design (see movie promo photo).
This is still a work in progress as I want to add some props to go with her.

This model is refreshingly easy to make. No scale or orientation changes need be applied.
High resolution is recommended and was used to print the model in the photos.
Rafts are recommended for each piece but supports are only needed for the head piece.
After printing, you assemble with glue, prime and paint!

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

This is a PID controlled heater installation for the Replicator 1 3D printer. For printing in ABS I have found that having the replicator enclosure nice and warm is critical to getting good results, and that if it is at the right temperature range a cooling fan will help reduce distortion and aid spanning gaps. See my attached picture of thing 233094, it was printed post heater install with no support and has had no clean up done.

DISCLAIMER: Assume that I'm an idiot (It's the safer assumption), attempt this modification at your own risk! UPDATE:
It seems I will not be getting Bottlework's Aluminum Arm upgrade, he has canceled my order and "BANNED" me from ordering from him! This transpired over a difference of opinion relating to the definition and purpose of the PayPal Resolution Center. For those of you who don't know, PayPal has a Resolution Center where you can Dispute a transaction WITHIN 45 days of payment, which is there to resolve issues between the consumer and the Seller. Bottleworks believes that the only reason to file a dispute is if you are demanding a refund, but I see it as a tool to cover myself in case anything happens. In short, I filed a PayPal dispute on the 44th day since ordering to cover myself should I have an issue and Bottleworks got upset (canceling the order and "Banning" me). If I had not filed the dispute I would have lost the protection PayPal provides, which is the point of using PayPal. I should mention I did the same thing on my HBP order for the same reason, although that time I warned him repeatedly that I would do so. Some short advice when dealing with Bottleworks, just from my experience.
  • Don't expect timely delivery, or accurate timelines. (4 weeks isn't accurate, nor were the ETA's I was given upon inquiry).
  • Don't expect the item to ship when you receive the tracking information. (In my case, I had the tracking number for a week with no movement).
  • Don't expect him to be understanding or reasonable if you do what I did. He will simply cancel your order and refuse to work with you.
  • If you are missing documentation, don't expect him to provide it. At the time I received the HBP the Makerware profiles link on his page was dead, and my email request for a copy was ignored.
    • I'm going to have to pursue an alternative upgrade to these arms, if I come up with something comparable and cheaper to make I'll post the information/plans on Thingiverse under a free licence. I have found that setting the temperature to approximately 110 F produces the best results. 120 actually leads to extruder problems, and the cooling fan is not as effective leading to more pronounced warping. I have installed the heat sinks on the x/y stepper motors. While I believe this may be a futile attempt to protect them, I feel better having done something. I used 20 11x11x5 heat sinks to allow me flexibility in placement. I've added pictures detailing their placement. Note: The heater I chose was designed for heating enclosures and features a positive thermal coefficient ceramic heating element which is safer in that as the temperature gets closer to a dangerous level the heater will reduce it's heat output. However, I wouldn't suggest leaving it unattended for any length of time. After installing Bottleworks' HBP upgrade I found that the internal temperature of my enclosed replicator was not getting nearly as warm as it used to because the HBP is more efficient and isn't run nearly as hot. So I set out to find a way to increase the internal temperature of the Replicator 1 in a controllable way. Left to do:Install Bottleworks' Aluminum arms upgrade, add inline fuse to AC in, and add solid state relay to utilize PID solid state output (clicking can be annoying). Step 1. Implement the MightyBoard Airflow Rework or some variation of it, you don't want to be heating your MightyBoard. I've linked those upgrades under this thing's sources. Step 2. Order Parts, I've listed the main components I used here, although your implementation is bound to vary. Parts:
    Replicator 1 printer which you don't mind potentially damaging.... JLD7100 Digital Display PID Temperature Controller: Amazon.com -$32.50 USD http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004HIRSGK/ref=oh_details_o02_s00_i01?ie=UTF8&psc=1 1M (3.3ft) K type Thermocouple for PID temperature controller: Amazon.com - $1.98 USD http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004HHXZB8/ref=oh_details_o02_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
    Integra DIN6 DIN Rail Kit, 2 Rails, 4 Screws, 6" Nominal Length: Amazon.com - $10.31 USD http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B007EWUK5M/ref=oh_details_o01_s01_i01?ie=UTF8&psc=1 12V 2A DC Universal Regulated Switching Power Supply: Amazon.com - $5.82 USD http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B002FH54L6/ref=oh_details_o01_s00_i01?ie=UTF8&psc=1 Omron G7L-2A-BUBJ-CB DC24 General Purpose Relay With Test Button, Class B Insulation, Screw Terminal, Upper Bracket Mounting, Double Pole Single Throw Normally Open Contacts, 79 mA Rated Load Current, 24 VDC Rated Load Voltage: Amazon.com - $10.57 USD http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B005T74294/ref=oh_details_o01_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 1 Flyback Diode to protect your MightBoard from your Relay's coil discharge. Cirrus FGC1007.2R Enclosure Heater 120/240VAC 12v DC Security CCTV Heat Camera: Ebay.com - $71.97 USD http://www.ebay.com/itm/221206290359?ssPageName=STRK:MEWAX:IT&_trksid=p3984.m1423.l2649 SPST 16A 125V Illuminated Round Rocker Switch with Red LED: radioshack - $4.49 USD http://www.radioshack.com/product/index.jsp?productId=3118987 Antec spot cooling fan: Can't remember where I got this, it was left over from my old PC I tore down a few years back. However it can be found online and is called "Antec Spot Cool Case Fan". Power Socket: Stolen from an old power brick for an HP Printer I no longer own.
    Misc Scrap Wire I already owned, old power cord for the high voltage, PC wiring for the low.
    Misc Nuts and Bolts used for mounting. Tools:
    Soldering Iron, Drill, Hole Saws, Coping Saw Step 3: Assembly
    Mounting:
    The PID controller and switches are mounted in the front of the Replicator, under the printer floor but above the protective bottom plate. The file for the simple face plate I made is attached. The power socket is mounted in the back left of the underside of the printer, be sure to carefully shield the wiring here, there is no protective plate. Other Items are simply mounted underneath through the floor of the printer as needed. Current Functionality/ General wiring description: 120 VAC comes in through the back power socket and is wired in parallel to the 24V DC NO Contact relay AND the right most switch on the front display (Live wire being switched). (To do, Add inline fuse in case of short) Both the Switch(mentioned above) and the relay go the PID controller and the 12v DC switching power supply. So, when either the switch or relay is engaged both the PID controller and 12V power supply have 120VAC power. The PID Controller is wired to supply 120 VAC to the heater, while the 12V power supply powers the 12V fans on both the heater and the fan mounted next to the heater for circulation. In other words, if the heater switch is on, the fans are running regardless of if the controller is actually sending voltage to the heater element. (Note, the fan mounted to my extruders that blows across the print is run off 5 volts stepped down from the 12 volt supply and controlled by the second switch on the front display) The 24V relay is wired to the Extra output on the mighty board with the FLYBACK DIODE IN REVERSE POLARITY across the terminals. I can't emphasize enough the importance of the diode, I actually soldered them to the wires so if it came loose I wouldn't forget it or connect it in the wrong polarity causing a short. This allows the control of the heater systems power from the MightyBoard using G-code commands. (The idea being you turn on the switch to preheat, and once the print begins the relay is engaged allowing you to turn the switch off without powering down the heating system. Once the print finishes the relay is disengaged and the heating systems turns off). The second NO contact on the 24V DC relay is wired to the brass contact on the right switch (power) and the Neutral wire of the 120VAC. This turns the light on that is embedded into the switch when the relay is engaged, giving me a visual indication of when it's safe to toggle the power switch to off without cutting power to the heating system. The thermocouple is run under the insolation I have added on the floor of the printer and pops out in the right front corner of the printer opposite the heating element. Summary:
    When the power switch is turned on, the heater and heating fans are turned on, the PID settings determine if the heating element has heat. The second switch manually turns on my extruder mounted cooling fan, but is dependent on the heater power being engaged. When/if the extra output is utilized to turn on/off at the beginning and end of the print, the 24VDC relay is engaged, turning on the power switches red light and effectively shorting the power switch out of the circuit allowing it to be turned off. At the end of the print the extra output turns off, turning the heater off with it. You may notice the hood has a Reflectix Hat on in some of the pictures, it looks ridiculous but really speeds up the preheating and allows for higher temperatures to be obtained, (I've hit 118 F without the heater running with the hat on, and just preheating via the printer controls).

title: DIY Dummy Battery Emulator Adapter AA

description.text:
This is a great way to power your battery powered device from an AC power source or from a DC / USB power source as I have in this project. The idea was to retro fit some dummy batteries into my portable speaker, so that I could use a 15000 mAh dual USB port power bank to power the speaker (and the mobile / cell phone) for longer duration's whilst out and about.   
Just by chance, a friend was moving out and he had lost the AC power adapter for his iPhone / iPod docking station and he said that I could have it. Great! However, I quickly found out that it would only last for a few hours before the batteries needed changing again. I thought about it and decided to make some solder free dummy batteries to emulate the batteries. I wasn't sure at first if the 5V delivered over USB was enough so I did a quick test and it worked fine. 4 x 1.5 Volt batteries would be 6 V and not 5 V, so I measured the state of some old batteries that I used in the device before it failed and they fell to about 1.1 Volt each, giving you a combined 4.4 V. Seems its might run along the bottom line at times, but it sounds great, even at high volumes :)  
Now I have wired it up to the USB battery and all the four LEDs on the USB battery are still active after 6 hours of music! Seems that the average, decent battery is about 1000 mAh, so this is the equivalent of 15, instead of 4 ;)  
Works a treat. Hope this helps someone as it did for me.  
3D Printed on a Ultimaker 3D Printer

Once printed, strip your connecting cables back about two small finger lengths and twist the ends. Feed the bare cable through the bottom hole and back through the top. Twist the cable to itself and use a cable tie to fasten the cable in place. If need be, drill a big enough hole for the cables in the cover of your device' battery compartment and also think about making two extra holes for a cable tie to fasten the cables in place to make sure they don't get yanked at any point.

title: Bowden Syringe Extruder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This thing makes it possible to extrude liquids and gels with no heavy parts on the carriage of your machine. It features a 10ml syringe that feeds the moving end via a 3/2mm tube. On the moving end is a standard luer connector, so you can connect different types of nozzles.

Cut out the frame parts with a lasercutter from 4mm plywood. You might need to adjust the offset to compensate for the width of the laser kerf.
Print out the printed parts. Cut 2 8mm shafts to size and cut& drill the trapezium screw. The screw is glued directly to the motor axle, so I drilled this hole on the lathe.
Assemble the wooden case but leave off the side where the syringe slots in. You probably need to put the motor screws in the other sides before assembling, which means you also need to put the thumb wheel in there... (yes a next version should be easier to assemble). Once you are ready for it, put enough (but not too much) epoxy glue on the mating surfaces from the thumbwheel with the screw and the motor axis, and glue the three together.
Insert the 'trapezium nut' first, then slide the 8mm shafts in their slots, fixing the nut between them.
For connecting the tube to the syringe or tip, I cheated and used what I had on hand: a cut off tip with luer lock (and some sugru) connects the tube to the syringe, the tip on the end has this same tube jammed into it. Once I get ahold of some proper luer lock tubing I'll update the parts. :) This part mounts on thing... (TODO published earlier)
And lastly: I do not grant any special rights to makerbot or thingiverse. It's CC-NC-SA and that is good enough for publishing it here.

title: Camera repackage and mount for Creative Live Cam Sync and Solidoodle 3

description.text: Bought this camera to do time-lapse and monitor my Solidoodle 3 while using OctoPrint/OctoPi: Creative Live! Cam Sync HD 720P Webcam http://amzn.to/PEtRg6 Wanted a smaller package and a low profile mount so I came up with this. Let me know how this works, I considered putting a case around the whole thing but like the skeleton look.

• Start printing out both parts.

  • While that's happening, gently disassemble your camera, save all 4 screws.
    • 3a. When the camera board holder is done printing, you can use the screws that come with the camera to assemble. The two smaller screws are for affixing the circuit board to the rectangular board holder. 3b. There is a cut out which allows for the rubber microphone holder to slip in and under the board to retain the microphone, or you can let it dangle or just desolder/clip.

  • Once the camera is mounted to the board, you can attach the mount to the board, one of the two larger screws is for connecting the Solidoodle mount to the camrea board holder.

  • Connect the USB cable to the OctoPi computer or whatever you're using. Enjoy!

author: illc0mm

description.text:
Heading towards a Raspberry Pi tablet, this is a case for a touchscreen LCD display that connects nicely to the Raspberry Pi.
Right now this case fits around the display as a separate unit from the Raspberry Pi, which you can put in any of the available Raspberry Pi cases on Thingiverse. My next step will be to fit the Pi into the same case. Oddly the thing preventing it is that HDM cables are so thick. Does anyone know where I could get (or parts to make) a flexible HDMI cable that's only a few inches long?
The design has been printed and iterated a few times, with the updates uploaded. Added a slot into which the power jack slides (bottom right side of the monitor), to better align the access hole on the back to the HDMI connector, and to enlarge the access slot for using the controls (bottom front). And added 'tabs' to hold the corners down. They eliminated curling when printing PLA (for me), but you'll have to break/cut them off unless you really like Mickey Mouse.
Still looking for an HDMI cable that's short and flexible, so that I can pack the Raspberry Pi into the display.

Buy http://www.benl.ebay.be/itm/Samsung-7-LED-LCD-Touch-Monitor-Kit-Out-Door-Industrail-Grade-Sunlight-Viewable-/110923590251?pt=US_Rear_View_Monitors_Cams_Kits&hash=item19d38faa6b . It is a durable 7" touchscreen with an HDMI input. It also has VGA and composite input, and it runs on a wide range of voltages, so it's used for in-car videogame and DVD player display, etc. Remove all of the cables that you don't need (VGA, etc.). Gently connect the video controller to the display (they come together, but aren't connected) and double-stick tape the video controller to the back of the display so that the connectors lie flat and the HDMI jack sticks out the back. Print top and back v6 STLs. Put display into the face, with the controls arranged below the display so that they're visible through the slot. Slide the power jack into the slot on the bottom right of the display Feed the USB cable through the HDMi hole in the back, and connect it to the Raspberry PI. Close the case Plug HDMI into the back of the display and into the Raspberry Pi. The connector should be directly below the opening on the back of the case. Plug power into the display (the jack on the side). Plug keyboard and power and an SD card with Raspian on it (download from raspberry.org) into the Raspberry Pi When you configure Raspian, turn off overscan, so the display uses the whole screen. Have fun!

Ok, So I got sick of seeing all of these Qi Wireless charging pads being required to either be flat for a cheap price or if I wanted it to be somewhat vertical, I'd have to pay an arm and a leg. Therefore, I took it upon myself to make a vertical dock for my Galaxy S4 Phone. Using a right angle Micro usb, a Qi Wireless adapter and a Qi Wireless charging pad, I made a dock out of it. Here are the links for the components you'll need. Wireless Adapter for a Galaxy S4 (other options are available, but this is what I have) http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00CU7FO5C/ref=wms_ohs_product?ie=UTF8&psc=1 Wireless Charing Pad (Again, other options are available but this is what I have) http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00BTORGSU/ref=wms_ohs_product?ie=UTF8&psc=1 Right Angle Micro USB http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00EBGGXS2/ref=wms_ohs_product?ie=UTF8&psc=1 This will also work with other Qi enabled devices (and even ones that arn't such as my Galaxy Note 8.0 which uses this as an adapter : http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00HI8JYFE/ref=wms_ohs_product?ie=UTF8&psc=1 Works great!
Take the cable, plugt it into the pad through the hole provided within the dock and then plug that into a USB port. Once this is done, just set your Qi enabled phone on the dock.

remixed_from.title: Replicator 2x Upgrade: Indexable Print Bed Leveling Nobs

title: Indexable Bed Leveling Knobs for Rep 2x

description.text: These leveling knobs help keep your bed level while making adjustments to your bed height. Each knob has a moveable scale that allows you to set a "zero" bed height. Plus, minus signs indicate an increase or decrease in bed height. The scale is non-specific and simply marks position; knobs are set in equal positions to maintain a level bed.

• Print out parts- shells 1, layer .2, infill 15% no raft, no supports; I recommend slower print speeds overall; slower speeds on outlines seem to produce more clarity on the scale bar
  • Press knobs from your bot into the printed knobs; vice works well.....the idea is to get them pressed in flat and straight.....be careful! don't break the knobs!
  • Add scale rings and screw knobs back onto your bot
  • Get your bed level - level your bed manually or use leveling script
  • Get your bed level! - print out a bed calibration print, make adjustments; print as many times as needed to get a full perfect print
  • Carefully hold the knob in place and spin the scale ring until the zero lines up with the plastic reinforcement rib on the underside of the bed. Do the same for the other two and you are now "zeroed"!
    • Now you can make adjustments to your bed up or down keeping it level the whole time. Remember you can use positions between tick marks as well for even finer adjustment.

Just another nut cap. I made it hexagonal all the way up on the outside as a tribute to form follows function and because I wanted to make it easier to print upside down. Personally, I have always thought the traditional metallic nut caps with the nut shape at the base and the rounded cap at the top are rather weird looking. A strange design someone probably came up with in the 19th. century and which hasn't change ever since. A design like a mechanical Wolpertinger (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wolpertinger). But now there is 3d printing, so I can design my own nut cap.. As you can see in the photos, our garden bench is now assembled with 17mm wheel nuts. Should someone care to ask why, that will give me the perfect excuse to start a min. three hour explanation of the reprap movement..

The scad file is supplied and it is fully parametric. You can adjust wrench sizes outside and inside, heights, number of objects on the stls etc.  
The prepared stls are for a flat M6 nut inside with 10mm wrench size and 17mm wrench size outside (because that was what I needed for my garden bench).  
The stls printed well and quickly with 20% infill. I fixed the caps to the nuts with a bit of adhesive.

author: Tomasw

title: Isolating Mount for TV Remote Control IR Blaster

description.text:
At my office we have a number of TV's out in public locations which are wired back to a stack of cable boxes. To do this we run HDMI over two Cat 5 Ethernet cables using StarTech HDMI Extenders. The HDMI extenders allow video to be sent over 30 meters using the ethernet cable and allow for remote control signals to be sent back to the box using an IR blasters. When you're just using one cable box this system works great! The IR blaster even comes with some double-stick tape so you can attache the blaster to the front of the cable box. However, when you have lots of cable boxes in a closet, things can get tricky. You end up having to use cardboard and tape in interesting ways to keep one blaster from changing the station on the wrong cable box. Enter the Isolating IR Blaster Mount. The mount makes it easy to isolate the output of an IR Blaster in a crowded environment. There are two versions:
  • One version simply holds the blaster and directs the output. This is great if you still have the double-stick tape that comes with the blaster.
  • The second version has an extra tab to make things easy to attach! Simply apply a strip of scotch tape. Voila!
    • The design has a small hole in the bottom to make it easy to remove the IR blaster if you decide to change your setup! Enjoy!

Step 1: Print
Step 2: Insert IR Blaster
Step 3: Attach to Cablebox
Step 4: Enjoy the ability to change channels from another room!

  • ammo holes have a flat side and a pin to hold the ammo securely
    • Blog posting:
    http://marcuswolschon.blogspot.de/2012/09/mount-nerf-gun-to-nerf-gun-with-ammo.html License is CC-BY-NC-SA
    So you may make one yourself and improve the design but not sell the design or made parts.

Usage should be obivous.
Print with the flat side in the holes up and the spike oin the holes down. Version 2 is less demanding to print in terms of sub-millimeter accuracy.
Because of the tall and slender nature of this thing you are advised to print with a raft even on a heated build platform. Version 2.1 has an 0.5mm tighter grip on the rail.
It is also 7 instead of 5mm strong and increased the distance of ther hole-centers to the edge from 9 to 10mm to make it survive harsh battles.
No other changes. Version 2.2 is even more sturdy at the expense of only 3 darts. Feel free to change the design to any other length.

This is my very last try to make it really fast.
There is no way without a wide stern part.
The other problem is the high bow wave which sprays water into the boat. You can avoid it by spray rails. This is not unusual on real boats.
With both improvements it runs pretty well and I think it is fast enough - at least for me ;-)
http://youtu.be/5ZNzgMwRtdA

Printing
The best is, if you print it with spiral vase methode. Then you will get a neat surface without any noses from layer change.
The hull is 3.0 mm thick.
I printed with layer hight: 0.3 mm and width: 0.6 mm.
Anyway, you have to print it hollow with one perimeter otherwise it will not fit inside the interface part. You can use the interface part from the motorboat enlarged. Holes in support
The holes in the support to fasten the motor mount must be melted out by a slightly modified bowed soldering bolt ( as shown in the photograph)
Don't use a drill, it will damage the material.

This is the Neuron, a learn to solder kit I threw together for the 2012 Kansas City Maker Faire. On the surface it's just another easy to assemble "my first soldering project" blinker, but put a few of them together and you can make a light and touch reactive light show! It functions as your typical alernating LED blinker with a jumper in place, but remove the jumper and they mirror pulses of light detected on one LED to the other. Chain a large set of them together and they'll activated each other in sequence. They're also bi-directional so you can send a pulse one direction in a chain and send another back the opposite direction. A single Neuron firing can activate more than one Neuron, forming branching light shows as well! You can even use one in blink mode to act as a convenient light pulse source.

Other features of note:
  • The bolts used to make the boards lay flat can be used with magnets to mount them on magnetic surfaces
  • In neuron mode, a piezo speaker can be connected to the mode jumper and each neuron will emit a random tone when it activates, or a specific tone with a slight firmware modificaiton
  • Neurons actively sample the ambient light so they can function fine under several different lighting conditions (they work best in low light, function fine in normally lit rooms, and don't work well in sunlight because the light saturates the sensors)
  • Touching the leads of an LED on a Neuron will activate it as well as light
  • The PCBs are one sided and are fairly easy to etch at home and the circuit itself if easy to assemble on a breadboard or perfboard
    • Full assembly instructions availiable here:
    http://www.built-to-spec.com/blog/kit-instructions/neuron-build-instructions/ You can see them on Adafruit Show-and-Tell here:
    http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0SnvDkEhwSQ#t=20m31s And here's a quick video I did demoing a set of them at the hackerspace:
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PmzQeHIHwlY Grab what's left of the v1.0 boards in my store:
    http://builttospecstore.storenvy.com/collections/120070-neurons The firmware was developed in AVR Studio 5, but should be easy to compile using avr-gcc under Linux. Note that in this version, the ISP header will not work with ISP programmers with inline current limiting resistors (like the tinyISP) once the LEDs are installed.

This is the world's first (mostly) 3D-Printed mechanical endstop switch (that I know of).
Recently I broke one of the end stop switches on my printer, so I decided instead of buying a new one, why not print one instead? This is my first attempt at making a 3d-printable mechanical end stop switch. I put it on my printer, and so far it has worked for dozens of prints. Head on over to instructions for more information on making it.
I can also add parametric files for those who would like to modify this design.

There are two types to chose from: V1 or V2. V1 is the one that I printed and is in the photos, but V2 design has been modified for easier printing and better performance. I haven't tested V2, but would recommend printing it.
The parts that you will need are pretty simple: just some wires, a spring from a pen, some tin foil, and a 10k resistor. (The resistor is not needed if you use internal pullup resistors on your printer's controller electronics.) You can look at the pictures to see how I wired it, it's pretty simple, I added tin foil to the switch's paddle and side to make the contacts, and then I added the wires and resistor to that.
Basically, I tried to make the circut described here: http://reprap.org/wiki/Mechanical_Endstop#Switch_wiring
A simple diagram of my wiring:
GND------------| |-----[signal pin]-----(10k resistor)----+5V

We dropped the bag from our Storz & Bickel Volcano Solid Valve Set and broke the plastic ring that keeps the end of the bag folded up against the valve enclosure. Turns out, we don't have to figure out how to order a new one - we can just design and print one! We made some adjustments to the original design that we think are improvements:
  • The teeth grip better into the groove on the valve.
  • Instead of being evenly distributed, the teeth are clustered where the groove actually is so they all fit into it.
  • The ring is deeper so it holds back more of the end of the bag and provides more of a surface to hold onto.

If you have ever used a 3d printer like the Dimension SST, you'll notice how there is little human interaction with the actual machine.  When you set up a print, the machine takes care of running a test extrusion and then cleaning the nozzle before centering itself.  With this in mind, I decided to try and get this working on my cupcake.  Skeinforge already has support for nozzle wipe, I just had to make the bracket.
So far I've gotten an initial center, extrude, wipe start file for skeinforge semi-working. I've made one print in which I started my machine cold and just clicked print.  I'll post it just as soon as the v2 firmware starts playing nice with my cupcake.

My bracket is for the heated build platform. I'm using the gap between the platform and the heated surface to help support the bracket.  You'll notice in the photo I've put springs on the bolts holding my heated build platform togeather.  I've found that this helps level my build surface.  The bracket includes four 5mm holes for mounting.  The recessed space in the bracket is meant to hold a small wire BBQ cleaning brush you can pick up at just about any hardware store. I've posted my source design so people can adjust this to whatever brush they find.
If you do not have a heated build platform, I believe there is an extra build platform in the cupcake cnc kit.  You can get some longer bolts and springs and build a set of staggered platforms like the heated build platform kit.

remixed_from.author: cyclone
remixed_from.title: Filament Colorizer - Marker Holder For 3mm filament

description.text: Colors your filament without printing any parts

Steps:
1>Drill 1.75mm hole in end of Sharpie casing
2>Remove Sharpie tip with needle nose pliers
3>Heat end of your filament with cigarette lighter about 20mm from end
4>pull the 20mm piece of filament away from heated section to create pointed tip
5>Cut stringed filament from pointed tip(make as smooth as possible)
6>Straighten about 15cm of filament after the pointed tip
7>Slowly insert pointed tip in to drilled out end of Sharpie
8>Filament may need to be rotated a few times to pass all the way through the Sharpie
9>Print Away!!!
10>I just use a piece of tape to cover the drilled hole when not in use.

comments.text: Needing help, I did what you said in the instructions but I cannot for the life of me get this to work. I have been able to on push the filament though once but when i try to get it ready for the printer itself the filament just wont go though the marker. I'm not sure what im doing wrong?
comments.author: lordmodder

comments.text: Its like threading a needle. The filament MUST be perfectly straight and filament MUST have perfectly pointed tip. I only tried 1.75mm filament. If the first attempt to pass filament through results in the marker's innards bunching up, it will be nearly impossible to re-thread. The innards of the sharpie are like a cotton ball inside a plastic tube. If you catch even one of the "cotton" threads while inserting, you are done. Pull sharpie body apart to investigate. (wear gloves)

comments.text: The trick is to melt the end of the filament with a lighter about an inch from the end, then pull the not melted part away slowly which will result in a pointed tip being created. Cut the end off the tip that has been created with something sharp. make sure the filament is completely straight then begin to insert it through the marker. If ANY resistance is met you must pull it back a small bit and maybe even turn the marker a tad bit to find a smooth route through. there are some pics of what the tip should look like after melting it in the photos. My hands were crazy blue too my first few attempts. after you get it down, it is pretty easy. Good luck, Mat

comments.text:
I just wanted to leave some notes on my experiences with this technique:
I first attempted to pass the filament through a red sharpie with the end result of splattering myself with red sharpie ink (DO NOT USE RED FOR YOUR FIRST ATTEMPT!!!) and breaking off the filament inside the sharpie. I did not pull the tip out with pliers I just cut it off/drilled it out. Which I think was my problem.
Undeterred I hand colored 6ft of 3mm white PLA filament with a purple sharpie. The resulting filament was a lovely purple but the color rubbed off rather easy (before extrusion), the resulting print came out more of a lavender color and uneven. I also had some issues with layer delamination on single wall prints. I think the white colorant already in the filament was cause of most of my problems, I want to try again with natural filament. It is also possible that the increased volume to filament ratio of the 3mm filament is affecting the color of the print.
Lessons learned:
Don't start with a red sharpie
Try in areas and wearing clothing you don't care about
Red on White comes out a really nasty shade of salmon pink
Purple on White comes out an ok shade.
Preparing filament ahead of time is a bad idea
Follow instructions
comments.author: The-Programer

I am hoping to not have layer lamination issues with white filament. I have NO lamination issues with Natural PLA. title: Vivitar Tripod Quick release Camera adapter

description.text:
This quick release camera adapter was made for my Vivitar Tripod to replace the missing camera adapter that came with the Tripod.Now I have made several and it is nice to have one dedicated for each camera.  
When printing this, it worked best without the support for the undercuts, and fit right into the tripod. When printed with supports, it took a bit of effort to remove the extra material.  
If your tripod is a different model, I included the skp file so you can modify the dimensions to fit your tripod.

I modeled the quick release adapter with layers of cardboard to make sure I understood how the quick release adapter was supposed to work. Then I used a vernier caliper to find the critical dimensions for the part and created the model with Sketchup using the measured dimensions. On the third iteration, the part worked perfectly. This part allowed me to use a tripod that was useless without the quick release adapter. On the first two iterations, I printed the part with supports for the undercuts. By printing without undercuts in the third iteration, the part fit into the tripod without the hacking and scraping required for the first two iterations.

author: karlsnyder0

description.text:
A printable clutch (purse, evening bag, etc) for desktop 3D printers. I've been a big fan of Zomboe's things, and have been eyeing his chainmail designs since I bought my TOM last year. There are lots of 3D printed fabric applications for pro-grade printers on shape ways, etc, but not for use on reprap or makerbot style printers. Building some awesome and wearable feminine accessories has been on my to do list for awhile. Goals:

  • Functional purse that will hold an iphone.

  • Print and assemble without glue

  • Attractive and durable enough to actually use.
    • I did not succeed on these counts. This project is less a work in progress, than an abandoned proof of concept. But, it's time to get it off my hard drive and out on the web. I expect to try again, with some lessons learned. The problems:

  • This took 24 hours to slice in RepG. That's longer than I want to wait, and too long to iterate quickly. I either need to simplify the geometry somewhat, or use a newer and faster slicer.

  • It's difficult to get every corner to stick to the platform, especially with a second extruder interfering and prying up a loose ends. Aggressive solutions like applying ABS slurry to the platform result in a less than desirable surface finish, and a lot of kapton tape to peel off the print. One missing square, and the print is ruined. There are about 5 holes in my print.

  • I haven't solved how the sides go together. Currently, I think a blanket stitch with plastic lacing used in kids' friendship braclets or embroidery floss should suffice. But it's not a great solution.

  • To be functional, this design really needs a chain or wristlet loop.

  • I could make a nicer looking design if I altered my approach from no-glue-snap-together, to allowing multiple pieces.

  • The hinge works well, but needs to be a little beefier to hold up.
    • I was happy with how pretty and shiny the fabric looks. With a more attractive shape and clasp, I'd wear it. There are cool options for textile prints with dual extrusion if I could just get everything to stick better. The "fabric" only bends in one axis on each side, which you should take into account if use it in another way.

I printed this very slowly, in attempt to help adhesion - 15 or 20 mm/s I think.  The piece is designed for .2mm layer height, though .1mm should also work well.  I printed with 5% fill, which wasn't sufficent, and the clasp snapped when I was stress testing it, I would think 25-50% should be better.  
If you're going to give the print a try, try the test swatch first to adjust settings if necessary.  
Print requires a larger bed (replicator, or larger)  
Print, carefully peel off platform.  Snap together hinge.  Sew sides shut :)  
Update: 27SEP12 - Realized I uploaded the wrong source (DWG)  file - file I included was missing the clasp.  New file uploaded.

author: CoffeeOutlaw

description.text:
Keep your headphones secured on a wall. There are no screw holes on this model as I didn't want to drill up my wall. I use sticky fixtures instead by Cellotape.  
Happy gaming

This is another classic robot, named Maria, from the 1927 science fiction movie "Metropolis".
I've recently updated the legs and torso to smooth a couple of areas.
Included also is a stand to mount her along with the consciousness transfer rings.
I took some poetic license with the details but it does capture the essence of the original design as seen in the movie poster photo.
The model was printed in PLA on a MakerBot Replicator 2.
This replaces the previous Maria.

The robot is printed in three sections.
Use high resolution and rafts.
Make sure the torso piece is upside down on the build plate.
Supports are only needed for the head piece.
You can print the rest of the props, stand, rings, and rings stand at low resolution.
Once printed, clean the robot up a bit (especially where the supports are), then assemble with glue, prime and paint!

description.text: My own version of what a spool holder should look like. It's a simple block with one hole and one indent. The holder is constructed using 3 m8 (or smooth) rods and 4 blocks. The whole sits on top of your prusa with 2 blocks and 2 other clocks are used to lay the spool on. The spool turns around one of the bars. In this design I used 2 ~28cm m8 rods and one ~18cm smooth rod I had around. The minimum recommended amount of nuts is 4. -UPDATE: For small (up to r=10cm) spools I've made this much better holder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:45588 . It uses only one piece of rod and no tools needed!

Needed:
3 rods (preferably, but at least 2 threaded)
2x ~30 cm
1x ~20 cm
4x m8 nut(or more, washers also optional) Build:
Print 4 of the blocks. Put a nut on each of the 2 m8 rods. Then put a block on each of them. On the other side of the rod, do the same: first a nut, then the block.
Stick the rods between the two upper bars on your prusa, the indent being filled by the bar the furthest away from you. Now you have 2 rods sticking out. Next, stick the remaining rod/bar trough the spool and 'lay' it on the indents on the blocks on the rods. Now you're done! If you need to change filament, just pick up the spool! No more undoing bolts!
A friend of mine is a Minecraft fan (just like me), and his birthday is next Monday, so I want to print something Minecraft for him, and ... voila!

Print  
Pause at certain height,  
Change filament (transparent blue would be ideal)

title: Icetube Clock Enclosure
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is an enclosure for the Adafruit Icetube VFD Clock Kit.

The enclosure requires 1 main body and 2 end panels, as well as a few extra parts: 8x M4 Socket-head Cap Screw (McMaster 91290A176)
8x M4 Hex Nut (McMaster 98676A200)
Jumper wire This enclosure works best with new Icetube kits because the angled header at the base of the VFD needs to be inserted differently (see images). It's possible to desolder the bracket and flip it, though, which is what I did. STEP 1
Connect the VFD breakout board to the main circuit board with jumper wire. I used pre-made 2" jumpers with little end sockets from Fry's, but you could just use a wire wrap tool. STEP 2
Slide the main board and the VFD assembly into the enclosure. STEP 3
Once you've lined up the buttons, power connector, etc with their respective openings in the case, click the mounting holes on the board down onto the corresponding pegs protruding from the bottom of the enclosure. STEP 4
Depending on how stiff your jumper wires are, you may need to attach a spacer to the inside of the enclosure end panel to keep the VFD tube pushed all the way through both openings in the enclosure. I used a strip of adhesive felt that was meant for keeping table legs from scratching the floor. STEP 5
Bolt on the ends of the enclosure.

description.text:
This fully assembled, print-in-place, functional belt is available now! Print it out yourself and wear it to hold your pants up. The entire belt and buckle can be printed on one build plate on the original Replicator. The belt in the picture was made in Transparent Blue MakerBot PLA on the Replicator 2, and it works perfectly. You should be able to fit over 7' of belt at this scale on the plate at one time. Looks great with matching High Heeled Shoes! http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:31218
Created by Todd Blatt

At this scale, the links are 14mm apart. The belt can be shortened by deleting links in the file, or by manually trimming them off once they're printed. With 64 links, including the last link, plus the length of the buckle, this fits through the belt loops of a standard person wearing 34" waistline jeans. This is the length of the belt in the justbelt.stl file and the belt with buckle.stl file. The shorterbelt.stl is a bit shorter. This was printed with 3 extra shells no infill. Use a raft if you're worried that not all pieces will stick to the platform. If you don't have it perfectly level, then some links might fail. For this to work, every link must print well.

title: 2014 Printrbot Simple Maker Edition Induction Probe Mount

description.text:
Update 5/7/14
Added the 18mm mount
New file: Stock_plate_probe_mount_18mm_RevA.STL Update 5/4/14
I've changed the 12mm probe mount to lower it by 20mm. Offset distance remains the same. If anyone needs the 18mm probe version right the way please let me know. Otherwise I'll update that one when I get a chance.
New file: Stock_plate_probe_mount_12mm_RevA.STL Update 5/3/14 I will have to modify these fittings to allow the probe to sit lower toward the bed. I did not realize that some of these probes do not have enough thread on them to be placed all the way down. This is an add-on to your 2014 Printrbot Simple stock aluminum extruder plate to mount the induction probe sensor for auto bed leveling feature. I have included both the 12mm opening for the Printrbot probe as well as the 18mm opening for the aftermarket Amazon.com probe. Update 4/26/2014
I've added 2 new integrated probe mounts. This gives a cleaner look plus you don't need to find 2 longer screws if you don't have them.
Stock_plate_integrated_probe_12mm.stl
Stock_plate_integrated_probe_18mm.stl Update 4/26/2014 v.2
This is yet another variation to the extruder plate. This version moves the probe mount 30mm x 30mm away from the hotend while adding a fan mount to face the extruder setup. If your extruder motor is overheating and/or skipping during print, add the 40mm fan to keep it cool. Stock_plate_integrated_extruder_fan_and_probe_12mm.stl
Stock_plate_integrated_extruder_fan_and_probe_18mm.stl

Option 1:
Print the part to mount your induction probe. You'll need 2 M3 screws that are 6mm longer than what you have now. The offset setting for the probe location is 0mm for Y and 30mm for X. Option 2:
For a cleaner look and not having to find 2 longer M3 screws, you can opt to print the extruder plate with the probe mount integrated. The probe offset is the same as option 1. Option 3:
This last variation for this mod moves the probe 30mm x 30mm away from the hotend and places the 40mm fan mount facing the aluminum extruder setup instead.

description.text: Simple, made with Design Spark Mechanical. My daughter was like, where are the [email protected]#! she wasn't impressed at all, so I added some taps as a separate file and melted them on with a lighter, now she's happy :) Does anyone have any concerns about melting/gluing PLA to complete things? I think it's pretty crude but saves a lot of messing around getting rid of support material. A tip I find is to never let the flame touch the PLA, and heat both parts to be connected at the same time with a bit of careful thought as to how to hold the parts, just as it starts to bubble I push them together and they are welded nicely. May be I'll add an updated file with taps & faucet built in the same object which doesn't need support if anyone says yes...

title: Three Eyed Raven (actually it's a Crow, just don't tell your friends)

description.text:
I used MeshMixer to add a third eye an existing crow model. Aside from my confusion about crows vs ravens, it was intended to be The Game of Thrones Three Eyed Raven that Bran uses Greensight to share his vision with.
You can see in the photos my print came out as  strange combination of success and failure. The "beard" is actually the support column's plastic being wiped off on the neck. After using a blade to remove the beard, there wasn't any real damage under the extra plastic. 
I printed in PLA, at starting at 175deg, but finishing around 180deg, after some tweaking. It was an early print for me, so I took it very slow.
